items.question: What is a clinical trial?
items.answer: A clinical trial is a research study that tests how well new medical approaches work in people.

items.question: Who can participate in a clinical trial?
items.answer: Eligibility varies by study. Each trial has specific inclusion and exclusion criteria.

items.question: Where are clinical trials conducted?
items.answer: Clinical trials are conducted in hospitals, universities, and research centers around the world.

items.question: What are some tutorials and resources for clinical trials?
answer: Master ClinicalTrials.gov: A Complete Walkthrough - A 30-minute detailed tutorial showing how to search, explore trial data, and submit studies on ClinicalTrials.gov. [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WMJFSFhOuFM](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WMJFSFhOuFM)

Finding Clinical Trial Information Using ClinicalTrials.gov - Explains searching, filtering, and understanding trial info from the Patient Engagement Manager at NAF. [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qOmnArOgyW0](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qOmnArOgyW0)

ClinicalTrials.gov Registration User's Guide and Live Demo - Step-by-step guide and live demo on registering studies and navigating ClinicalTrials.gov effectively. [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BkQh4VgXzVk](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BkQh4VgXzVk)

How to Use ClinicalTrials.gov - Beginner-friendly walkthrough covering basic search techniques and interpreting trial listings. [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GT1M0C6a2pc](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GT1M0C6a2pc)

ClinicalTrials.gov Official Training Webpage - Offers on-demand courses, demonstration videos, FAQs, and downloadable guides for researchers and educators. [https://learn.nlm.nih.gov/documentation/training-packets/T0162017P/](https://learn.nlm.nih.gov/documentation/training-packets/T0162017P/)

Protocol Registration and Results System (PRS) Guided Tutorials - Step-by-step tutorials on registering and submitting clinical trial data using the PRS platform. [https://clinicaltrials.gov/submit-studies/prs-help/prs-guided-tutorials](https://clinicaltrials.gov/submit-studies/prs-help/prs-guided-tutorials)
ALS Trial Navigator - Interactive online tool for personalized clinical trial matching with guided assistance. [https://als.net/](https://als.net/)

American Cancer Society Clinical Trial Resources - Educational resources and patient guidance on navigating clinical trials provided by ACS. [https://www.cancer.org/treatment/treatments-and-side-effects/clinical-trials.html](https://www.cancer.org/treatment/treatments-and-side-effects/clinical-trials.html)

items.question: What does 'Recruiting' mean for a clinical trial on ClinicalTrials.gov?
items.answer: The trial is currently enrolling eligible participants.

items.question: What is the difference between 'Not Yet Recruiting' and 'Recruiting'?
items.answer: 'Not Yet Recruiting' means the trial plans to enroll participants soon but has not started yet; 'Recruiting' means enrollment has begun.

items.question: What does 'Active, not recruiting' mean?
items.answer: Participants are still in the trial, but enrollment is closed.

items.question: What does 'Completed' indicate about a trial?
items.answer: The trial has ended, and all interventions and follow-ups are complete.

items.question: What is the meaning of 'Suspended', 'Terminated', or 'Withdrawn'?
items.answer: 'Suspended' is temporarily stopped, 'Terminated' is stopped early with participants, 'Withdrawn' is stopped before enrolling anyone.

items.question: Can a study be listed before IRB approval?
items.answer: Yes, it may be registered before IRB approval, but recruitment cannot start until approval is obtained.

items.question: How often does recruitment status need to be updated?
items.answer: Sponsors must keep the listing current, typically updating within 30 days of a change.

items.question: What is an 'Interventional' clinical trial?
items.answer: Participants are prospectively assigned to receive one or more specific interventions (e.g., drugs, devices, procedures) to evaluate their effects on health-related biomedical or behavioral outcomes.

items.question: How is an 'Observational' study different from an interventional trial?
items.answer: No intervention is assigned; researchers observe participants and measure outcomes without altering treatment or environment.

items.question: What are 'Patient Registries'?
items.answer: Organized systems that collect uniform data on patients with a specific condition or treatment over time, primarily for observational and long-term follow-up purposes.

items.question: What are 'Expanded Access' studies?
items.answer: Programs that allow patients to access investigational drugs or treatments outside of clinical trials when no comparable alternatives exist.

items.question: What is the 'Individual Patient' expanded access?
items.answer: A form of expanded access where investigational treatment is provided to a single patient under compassionate use protocols, often for serious or life-threatening conditions.

items.question: What is the 'Intermediate-size Population' expanded access?
items.answer: Expanded access for a group of patients larger than a single patient but smaller than a widespread treatment population, often used when some clinical data exist but formal approval is pending.

items.question: What is 'Treatment IND/Protocol' expanded access?
items.answer: A broader expanded access program under an Investigational New Drug (IND) application or protocol that allows treatment use of an investigational product for a larger patient group outside clinical trials.

items.question: What types of interventions are common in interventional trials?
items.answer: Drugs, biologics, medical devices, procedures (including surgery), behavioral or dietary interventions, radiation therapy, or strategies to diagnose, prevent, or treat disease.

items.question: What kinds of outcomes are measured in interventional vs. observational studies?
items.answer: Interventional trials measure effects of assigned interventions on health outcomes; observational studies measure associations or natural progression without intervention.

items.question: What do the different Phase numbers (I, II, III, IV) mean?
items.answer: Phase I: safety/dosage; Phase II: efficacy/safety; Phase III: confirm effectiveness, compare to standard; Phase IV: post-marketing studies.

items.question: Are all clinical trials phased, or do some have 'Not Applicable' phase?
items.answer: Non-drug/device studies may have 'Not Applicable' instead of a phase.

items.question: How does trial phase affect eligibility or trial purpose?
items.answer: Earlier phases have stricter safety criteria; later phases focus on broader populations and final validation.
